location.merchant_description_html: As I sit in my dark dungeon of doom (my cubicle), I’m overcome with longing. Food. Light. Beverage. Now. I head for Blue Glass Café. Open to all Bostonians, this bright and airy spot is the perfect lunchtime refuge. Usually I go for the hand-rolled Spicy Crab Roll. Today, I switch it up and heap my plate with greens, heirloom beets and Smoked Turkey at the pay-by-the-ounce Health Bar. Before I leave, I spot the inspiration for my next escape: I’ll be back for the Starbucks coffee bar, for sure.
location.street_address: 200 Clarendon St. (Coffee Shop in The Blue Glass Cafe)

location.merchant_description_html: I can’t stop thinking about her. I went to grab soup & a salad at Crave Sandwiches, but then I saw her: The 8th Wonder. She was thick as a dictionary, brimming with toppings and fresh, sliced-to-order meats including roast beef, salami and turkey. When I went back to see her again, I met with the Crispy Chicken Sandwich. Man, she knows how to dress! Thickly sliced mozzarella, roasted peppers and balsamic: mouth-watering. Now, I’m torn. I’m craving two delicious sandwiches at once...is this what pregnancy feels like?

The word “farm” doesn’t exactly fit on a 2nd Avenue block. But what’s in a name? That which we call a bodega by any other name would be as convenient. Anglophiles will be pleased to see rare British candies. For everyone else, there are 24 hours to find goodies among fresh produce, organic groceries, imported beers, and household necessities. Beware of feel-good Bollywood soundtracks that will lead to an over-shopping fever. Side effects include too many scoops of bulk trail mix.

My co-workers suffer from food lust. The last time I brought a Pesto Chicken Sandwich from Horn & Hardart, they left their cubicles in pursuit. So today, I’m eating-in at H&H. I order a comforting Classic Grilled Cheese. After, I grab a signature blended Green Tea Smoothie to go. Bad move. My co-workers feel the fresh chill as I pass their desks, and it sends them into a frenzy. I sprint to my office to sip as they weep at my door. Suddenly, Tom drops in from a ceiling vent, crazy-eyed, demanding my drink. This just got real.

How appropriate! The Statue of Liberty is a swim away from FiDi one-stop spot Cucina Liberta, Italian for “kitchen freedom,” where it’s all about options. Like a real life food blog, they curate the best from artisan producers and post them for us to eat: salad bar, hot buffet, deli sandwiches, bakery, sushi bar, and organic groceries. But they also create original content, like super thin crust pizza with fresh mozz and basil. Scroll the aisles, bookmark your favorites, click on your choice, and eat!

La Copa Loca means “the crazy cup,” and once you catch a glimpse of the flavor menu you’ll understand why. Outlandish gelato flavors jump out at you, pushing the limits of your taste bud imagination. There’s goat cheese, white chocolate basil, saffron, even extra virgin olive oil!  They sounds like Suess-ical concoctions...until you taste them. With over 86 flavors of rich, small batch gelato, the dessert adventures are endless. Hey, in no time ordering a “half goat cheese, half pumpkin” will come as naturally as, “chocolate, vanilla twist please!”

It’s always a good morning when I start the day with papusas at El Paraiso Cafe. What?! You don’t know what a papusa is? And you’ve been living in San Fran for how long? Kidding. Let me bring you up to speed on the art of an authentic Mexican breakfast. A papusa looks a little bit like a pancake, except it’s actually a handmade corn tortilla. And it’s not just griddled goodness, it’s filled with cheese, pork and beans. But, if you’re not in a papusa mood, you can always go the platanos route. Seriously? Man...they’re sweet fried bananas served with real crema. That’s it, forks up. Your tour de breakfast starts now.

Back in my college football days, I was a double sessions kind of guy. Now-a-days I’ve expertly transferred my love for double dosages to my career in Center City, Philly. Lunch time: I break from my cubicle in the Comcast Center building to post up at the Mexican Post. A Spicy Steak Burrito with Guac and a Blue Moon later (shh don’t tell el jefe) and it’s game over. That is until my post-game happy hour sweet and sour melon Rico Suave Margarita and Veggie Quesadilla. BOOM. Big win for my appetite.

It’s a multi-colored tropical storm of fresh ingredients when you eat at El Faro. Reds of diced tomato complement the vibrant fuchsias of crisp red onions, blending suavely across greens of smooth guacamole. Finally, lunch in the financial district can be quick, without having your options limited. Paint your culinary canvas with Zucchini Burrito Bowls, Fish Tacos or Super Quesadillas. Start the day off with a kick as early as 7 AM with some Huevos Rancheros. There’s no alarm clock like a little salsa picante!

At Tricolore Caffe, they live and work by the three F’s: fast, friendly, and fresh! You may order an Espresso with your freshly-made Zucchini Bread, but it will also come with the comforting ambiance of this Cafe. For lunch, get creative with a hand-stretched pizza, made with a healthy blended wheat crust and your choice of toppings. Stomach tugging in different directions? Try a combo: half Panini and a salad, two slices, or pizza and a salad, all for under $7. It’s the fastest way to fill up and stay satisfied.

I’ve got a challenge for you. Take everything you’ve ever known about coffee... and FORGET it. At Render Coffee, you’re in for an incredibly unique caffeine experience. There are no pre-made brews here. Each cup is made to order using a special pour-over method. The skilled baristas warn that a quality cup takes time: about four minutes to be exact. If you’re looking to relax, enjoy your morning coffee on the sunny, glass-enclosed patio out back. Coffee has so much more meaning at Render.

Tonight I’m taking a lady to El Sitio. I pull out her chair as she marvels at the brightly colored walls and wafting spices. The flavorful secrets of Uruguay,  Ecuador and Argentina are infused into dishes like citrus-marinated Shrimp Ceviche. She insists I try her Lomo Manchego: a succulent sirloin medallion, cloaked with manchego cheese. I brought along wine so we sip as we explore the menu, right down to the Tres Leches dessert. As we leave, she pinches my cheek. I totally just got the grandson of the year award.

Are you N the audience?  Be prepared to be part of the yoke! Every week, the N Crowd performs 80 minutes of unscripted, totally improvised comedy that relies heavily on audience participation! It’s “Who’s Line Is It Anyway?” meets “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” in an intimate 45-seat theater. It’s Old City, but these are new punchlines. The troupe only performs on Friday nights. Grab your $15 ticket and kick off the weekend right!
location.name: The N Crowd

location.merchant_description_html: Fabio & Danny’s Cafe may be located inside of Wayne Train Station, but it’s hardly just for commuters. People come from surrounding towns and cities for a taste of Nonna’s sweet pizzelles with Nutella. These lacy waffle cookies are gone before Nonna puts away the iron, so secure one while they’re hot! Additionally, sandwiches, pizzas, burgers and pasta depart F&D’s faster than the SEPTA, en route to stomach satisfaction station (M-F: 5:45AM-4PM, Sat: 9AM-2PM.) On Friday night things really slow down. Patrons with their own booze in tow fill Fabio & Danny’s for a long night of live music, slow dancing and smooth sipping.

Baisi Thai. Sure they boast incredible Pad Thai and Gaeng Daeng, but from first glance you may not gather two of the most impressive aspects of the spot. 1) They have delicious sushi. One look at the uber-realistic Red Dragon Roll will tame you. From it’s onion eyes to it’s flared lettuce mane, this dish has fierce personality. The real meat is found in the dragon’s back where each cucumber vertebrae is topped with rich pink slabs of tuna and fiery chili tobiko. 2) The view. Through the floor to ceiling windows, it’s Lake Michigan as far as the eye can see. I’m glad they don’t give away all of their secrets in the name. I’m 2 dragons away from getting my name engraved on a window seat.

You live the fab Fort Point life, darling. The waterfront is your playground. Seafood rules your world in summer, and lights twinkle off of the harbor in winter. Barrington Coffee Roasting Company, your morning coffee spot, is magical too. Aromas of local brews swirl as friendly, coffee-impassioned staff brighten your day. They use a top-of-the-line Synesso espresso machine, with the most advanced barista-controlled pressure profiling available. Translation: it’s a serious commitment to quality, hand-crafted espresso. Starting the day with a quality cup on the waterfront? Too fab, darling.

Tucked away in an unassuming office park in Burlington is the answer to every reverse commuter’s prayers: Servizio Cafe. When the clock strikes “chow time,” give your brown bagged lunch a Garnett-worthy slam dunk into the trash...soft, bubbly, herbed focaccia bread awaits! At One Wall Street, they’re all about fresh: House-sliced Boar’s Head meat and cheese. Crisp, colorful veggies and toppings. Warm, baked bread, in nine varieties! And though the design-your-own menu is always satisfying, be sure to check the specials, lest you miss out on an Ahi Tuna Sandwich or a Fried Scallop Roll.

I need my liquids if I’m going to focus on anything for an extended period of time. Give give me a large cup of strong coffee and freshly squeezed fruit juice and the word "impossible" flies right out the window. Siena Espresso and Juice Bar offers up the perfect kick-start to any undertaking. The Apple Carrot Beet juice is a personal favorite, but all the juice combos are equally refreshing. Throw in a perfectly roasted cup of joe, and you’re ready to memorize the dictionary...not that you would want to.

At Burger.org you can pick which 100% organic meat you’d like to grace your bun. Oh…Not a fan of organic? Well, here organic is synonymous with quality and flavor. Forget that artificial patty that could potentially bounce to the ceiling if dropped—you want high quality, flavor-packed, Burger.org grub. Just so you know—these burgers have better bunz than a Kardashian. Alas, your jealousy is futile. Trade in your Haterade for one of their tasty organic smoothies, and get your burger on (thank us later).

Meet Miss Asia, but don’t get the wrong idea. Miss A is not a prim, proper chef. She’s no stranger to fierce flavor. Her Thai-style Red Curry Chicken is simmered in coconut milk and intense red curry alongside peppers, bamboo shoots and basil leaves. Still not convinced? Her Fresh Spring Rolls swaddle ripe veggies in thin translucent noodle paper. Take these for a dive in the zing-worthy peanut sauce! Finally, sample the Papaya Salad. It’s a surprising medley of papaya, carrots, shrimp, beans and roasted peanuts in a finger-lickin spicy lime dressing. Three countries, three hits...this Miss can’t miss.

I just can’t hate on any establishment that dawns a pic of John Travolta on the wall. I mean, could you? When my Saturday Night Fever kicks in and I need a little thrust for my crust, I head to Nino’s in Beacon Hill. Open since 1971, Nino stays true to his Italian roots. Pizza in Italy is simple. The freshest ingredients for a sweet sauce, the right herbs for a savory aroma, and most importantly, mouth-watering melted cheese. Oh and one last essential: serve beer and wine. Oh yeah. Now we’re groovin’.

I’m a simple dude. Lunch is a sandwich and the occasional date-seeking salad. Up until now I had categorized Mediterranean as a UFO: An Unidentified Food Option. Turns out, “Mediterranean” is code for “huge helpings of meat, 10-inch gyros, all under $10.” Welcome to my palate revelation. Now I feast on juicy shawarma: meat that is slow roasted on a rotisserie until crispy. I snack on fully loaded hummus plates, garnished with falafel. Even salads step it up Med-style. Greek salads contain festive toppings like tomato, cucumber, feta and kalomata olives. I’m Dan and I am proudly a Maniterranean.

Get ready to become Japanese royalty. Roll up to the swanky couches in the back lounge. Streams of blues and purples provide ample mood lighting. A neon DJ booth features live spinning on the weekends, and a glowing wall highlights Chicago’s largest selection of sake bottles. Sample small plates like panko-crusted Chicken Yakitori Skewers, soy-flavored Yaki Rice Balls, or opt straight for a private karaoke room. Jeez, I thought royalty didn’t have to choose?! A sake-soaked song? You got it.

Consistency is Hamilton Deli’s middle name. Just kidding. It’s a deli, it doesn’t have a middle name. What it does have, though, is a long list of hunger-squashing sandwiches and burgers at both locations. I’m a sucker for The Insult, an 8 oz burger topped with thick chili, hot peppers, and melted cheddar. The fries are equally satisfying and always crisped to perfection. All that and I still haven’t mentioned the salad bar, which has over 50 different ingredients including Jamaican Jerk Chicken. KA-POW!

Ouch. You’re THAT kid…the one whose mom packed him a wack lunch and sent him to school to face the Lunchables. At least that’s what you look like next THIS guy… your co-worker who went to Al’s State Street Cafe for lunch. Al’s Bag Lunch is a winner: a soda, chips and any 10” sub or wrap for only $7.50! There are tons of choices ranging from a chunky Chicken Salad Wrap to a supremely seasoned Sicilian Steak sub, adorned with plum tomatoes and mushrooms. Come on guy, this is FiDi! Grab your big boy lunch and let’s get to work!

This place might as well be called “Katy’s Living Room.” The cozy, community vibe lures Central District dwellers away from sterile chain caffeine-eries with conversational baristas and delicious homemade pastries. Katy, the always-present owner and chief flavor suggester openly invites people to bring +1’s of all sorts: kids, laptops, even dogs! Though the clientele is diverse, everyone can agree that the White Coffee is the signature menu item. The beans in this brew aren’t fully roasted, so there’s significantly more caffeine.

Boom! Awake and feed your body and soul, drowsy student. That sound you hear?  Oh, that's just the "Tin Drummer" of Tin Drum Asia Café, leading your appetite downtown for a hot bowl of Coconut Soup. Between classes, feast on a zesty, stir-fried lunch of Pad Thai with thin rice noodles in a Thai Citrus sauce, or Lo Men with thick Chinese egg noodles in a Thai-brown sauce. The run shouldn't wind you too much, since the café is located right in the heart of Georgia State's campus.

Nothing is better than freshly brewed coffee and long conversations with friends, unless you're at Inman Perk Coffee. In that case, the saying should include baked Pizza Focaccia, Raspberry Cheese Paninis and free WiFi. The family-run business prides itself on making lasting relationships with every customer and is a staple in the "oldest neighborhood in Atlanta." Stop by for an Iced Chai or Fruit Smoothie and enjoy the local gallery featuring pieces by emerging artists, updated monthly. You'll feel right at home.

At Anatolia Cafe & Hookah Lounge, you'll never have to worry about "puff, puff, pass" again. However, you WILL have to grow an extra pair of hands. How else will you enjoy cheap drinks, authentic Turkish food, and master the art of blowing a ring through a ring? When you aren't hitting the hose, new dilemmas pile up elsewhere. Do you get the lamb gyro and fries, or the Iskender, with shaved lamb on top of pita, tomato sauce and yogurt? Now you just need to get an extra stomach. Problem solved.

Your coworker’s face droops like his lifeless pizza slice as he moans the greasy takeout blues. But you’re boogying to the cumin and coriander jig. The harmony’s off, so give him something to sing. An intro of fresh doughy Naan starts the groove. For the verse? A Samosa. The spicy potato and green pea fried pastry will have even the shy woman from HR singing along. The hook: Tawa’s Chicken Tikka Masala boasts BBQ meat in spicy tomato curry with butter and fresh cream. That’ll be stuck in your head for days.
